fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25445].
  {panel}

The context calculation tries to imply which project/issue type combinations are possible for a particular query. For example, {{project = JRA}} generates the context (JRA,*) (i.e. Project = JRA with any issue types). We use this on the issue navigator to only display custom fields in context (e.g. a custom field that is only visible in the CONF project will not have its column renderered) and doesItFit(TM) calculation. The "was" clause does not generate the right context.

# Restore [^data.zip].
# Run the query {{status = monkey}}. Notice that the "Monkey Custom Field" is displayed. This is because the context for this query is (MKY, *) as the status monkey only exists in the Monkey project.
# (DEFECT) Run the query {{status was monkey}}. Notice that the "Monkey Custom Field" is *NOT* displayed. This is because the context for this query is calculated as (*, *). The context for this query should also be (MKY, *).
fields.summary: Context calculation for was clauses is broken.
JQL autocomplete does not suggest list operand for the DURING condition.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25436].
  {panel}

Based on the docs, I used issue.key as a velocity parameter on the web-fragment, assuming that the Issue object would be in the velocity context under "issue". This works on the view issue page. Unfortunately, when the issue operation is rendered on the issue navigator, the issue parameter isn't in the velocity context - only the issueId parameter is present.

I'd expect both of these to contain the same velocity parameters when rendering. If they don't, then the documentation should be updated so developers know what parameters they can rely on here.

See getIssueOperations() in IssueNavigator for where the IssueOperations get their velocity parameters (well, velocity parameter) in the issue nav.

Caused https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BON-18
fields.summary: Velocity context present for issue operation web items doesn't contain "issue" when rendered in the Issue Navigator

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25429].
  {panel}

Statuses in a visual workflow show *Step Name (id)* values as opposed to *Linked Status* values.

Since the *Step Name (id)* value is really only shown in the Steps Editor (and nowhere else throughout the JIRA UI), visual workflows should be reflecting *Linked Status* values instead.

By implementing this fix, then whenever the JIRA (project) administrator edits the name of a status in the VWD's status editor, the name change should be reflected in the visual workflow (and for ordinary JIRA users, the workflow view of JIRA issues which use that workflow).

Bear in mind that changing a status' name in the VMD affects all other workflows that use the same status. This is considered expected behaviour. To create a status that's workflow-specific, the JIRA (project) administrator would need to create a completely new status (i.e. *Linked Status*) to use in the workflow.
fields.summary: Statuses in a visual workflow show 'Step Name (id)' values as opposed to 'Linked Status' values.

Create an issue with the summary

Test issue Mon Jun 20 12:28:20 PDT 2011

such as https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/TST-29105

Then search for that issue using JQL:

summary ~ "Test issue Mon Jun 20 12*"

The issue is found, possibly along with some other issues.

Now search for the same issue with 

summary ~ "Test issue Mon Jun 20 12:*"

This error is displayed:

Unable to parse the text 'Test issue Mon Jun 20 12:*' for field 'summary'.

Please document this limitation at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Advanced+Searching#AdvancedSearching-characters or even better describe how to escape a colon in this case.

fields.description: As a multilangual tool, JIRA should allow administrators to publish announcement banner in as many languages as the field they play in is asking. Let's say we have people on the team from Russia, USA and France working on the same JIRA instance. Announcement banners should be available in Russian, English and French depending on user's language setting.
fields.summary: Make announcement banner multilangual compliant

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25417].
  {panel}

We've had situations where some project roles (i.e., such as Project Manager's) that do not wish to receive automatic e-mail notifications when their issues are updated, created, etc. while others in the same role/group do.  Since subscriptions can only be created for personal use or group(s) their still is not a way to create some form of subscription for those who do or do not wish to receive notifications.  And even if there was the system would send the results of the subscription to all in the group vice just the assignee.  Suggest implementing one of two systems.

#1) Allow each person to have the option on their profile to either 'receive' or 'not receive' automated notifications from JIRA.  This scheme involves just notifications, not subscriptions. 

#2) Add functionality within the subscription feature to allow adding project roles and/or individuals to the subscription.  You can setup a group with only one individual now but the extra steps seem totally needless to achieve the same results.  Moreover, with this add an additional option of sending the subscription only to those who are affected (i.e., the assignee, reporter, project, or a configurable paradigm setup by the JIRA Administrator).

Both the notification schema and subscription functionality is a power feature to help keep on top of things.  Adding one or both of these recommendations would simply make this a much more powerful capability.
fields.summary: Additional Functionality for Automated JIRA Notifications

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Login to JIRA.
2. In the administration, go to "General Configuration".
3. Set the "Allow users to vote on issues" to "off".
4. Check activity stream for any issue where user is not reporter.

Result:
1. The "Vote" link is still there. Clicking on that gives "An unknown error occurred while voting."
fields.summary: User is still allowed to "Vote/Watch" on issue through activity stream when the setting is globally set to "off".
JQL for "WAS" "DURING" not working properly

fields.description:
The {{LabelService.getLabels(Long customFieldId)}} methods falsely advertise that they accept *null*.
Either the JavaDoc for all the {{LabelService.getLabels(Long customFieldId)}} needs to be changed to say that the *customFieldId* must be provided
or the methods need to be changed so that it truly accepts *null*

The JavaDoc states 
{code}
    /**
     * Returns all the labels for the given issue and custom field.  The custom field may also be null, in which case
     * the labels for the system field will be returned.
     *
     * @param user The user performing the operation
     * @param issueId The issue id that the label is linked against
     * @param customFieldId Custom field id for the labels CF or null if it's the system field.
     * @param pid  project id, to be passed during issue creation or for gadgets or project panels
     * @return A set of alphabetically ordered labels for the issue and custom field.
     */
{code}

However, if you pass null in as custom field ID, then you're going to get a {{NullArgumentException}} because the first thing that {{DefaultLabelService.getLabels(Long customFieldId)}} does is {code}        notNull("customFieldId", customFieldId);{code}

(I discovered this while working on an enhancement to limit Label suggestions to a project (JRA-23656). JRA-23656 should also be a bug, not an improvement. It is a regression from the behavior of jira-labels-plugin-2.4 that was used in Jira 4.1.2.)
fields.summary: LabelService API not correct

fields.description:
Search in the Issue Navigator seems to be failed to search according to the Date Picker Format after changing the User Prefer Language(eg. Russian).

1. Using English as User Prefer Language(User Profile)
2. Search an Issue With Created Date(eg. 1/Aug/11) in Issue Navigator(eg. Before Change Language.jpg)
3. Change User Prefer Language to Russian
4. Pick a date(eg. 1/Aug/11<in Russian>) at Date Created field from date picker
5. Invalid Date Format error appeared.
fields.summary: Invalid Date Format Error At Issue Navigator After Change User Prefer Language
the current server time and date on the session list is formatted does not use the format defined on the lookandfeel.jsp

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The {{jira-config.properties}} file ignores the parameter if there are blank spaces in the end of the line.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a {{jira-config.properties}} file inside the {{[$JIRA-Home|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/JIRA+Home+Directory]}} directory.
# Add the following to the file (note the blank space in the end):
{noformat:borderStyle=solid| borderColor=#6A8EB3 |bgColor=#F8F8F8}
jira.websudo.is.disabled = true 
{noformat}
# Restart JIRA

h3. Expected Results
Websudo would be disabled in JIRA.

h3. Actual Results
Websudo is *not* disabled.

h3. Notes
* This happens to any properties configured in the {{jira-config.properties}} file.
* This also happens for the {{jira-applications.properties}} file, which was used in older versions of JIRA.

h3.Workaround
Remove any blank spaces in the end of the lines.
fields.summary: jira-config.properties file does not ignore spaces in the end of lines

fields.description:
This issue was raised from https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/6771/add-user-picker-to-gadget

A developer is trying to add a user picker to a gadget but can't. I have looked into this further and there are a couple of things in the way.

* The resource dependency tree is messed up, to include the necessary resource it pulls in almost all of JIRA's css & javascript when it doesn't need to.
* When making a request for the users JSON an alert pops up saying the JIRA server cannot be contacted. This will need further investigation. I am thinking it has something to do with baseUrl.

The user picker should work with the following gadget.xml

{code}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<Module>
    <ModulePrefs title="Test Single User Picker" directory_title="Test Single User Picker">
        <Optional feature="gadget-directory">
            <Param name="categories">
                JIRA
            </Param>
        </Optional>
        <Require feature="views" />
        <Optional feature="atlassian.util" />
        <Optional feature='auth-refresh' />
        <Require feature="dynamic-height"/>
        <Require feature="oauthpopup" />
        #oauth
        #supportedLocales("gadget.common")
    </ModulePrefs>
    <Content type="html" view="profile,canvas,home">
        <![CDATA[
        #requireResource("jira.webresources:select-pickers")
        #requireResource("com.atlassian.jira.gadgets:common")
        #includeResources()

        <script>
            jQuery.ajaxSetup({baseUrl: "__ATLASSIAN_BASE_URL__"});
        </script>
                
        <select class="single-user-picker" id="userpicker" name="userpicker"></select>
        ]]>
    </Content>
</Module>
{code}
fields.summary: User picker does not work in Gadgets

fields.description:
If there is an ImportExportException during the AO restore then JIRA will fail to restore.

I considered this during the initial AO implementation and thought that preventing JIRA from completing the restoration was acceptable in the face of this failure. We should probably reevaluate that decision and see if it still makes sense.

Here's the problem: An ImportExportException gets triggered during XML restore. Maybe the AO file was corrupted. Maybe there's a bug in AO. Doesn't really matter. All that really matters is that we haven't fully populated the database with all the data the user expects to be present. So what do you do? Do you allow JIRA to startup and operate? The plugins will chug along but their data won't be in the right state. Will that corrupt all their user data beyond repair? Or will things basically "mostly work"?

But if we don't let them bring up JIRA how do we convey to the user what the problem is and how to fix it? Do we prevent them from using all of JIRA just because a plugin stumbles over a bug in ActiveObjects?
fields.summary: Errors during ActiveObjects restore prevent JIRA restore

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25361].
  {panel}

Make the JIRA Configuration Tool's '*Save*' button only save the configuration of the currently-selected tab.

The [JIRA Config Tool|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Using+the+JIRA+Configuration+Tool] is a convenient, multi-purpose tool, which our various installation and upgrade procedures make extensive use of.

However, one annoying aspect of this tool is that clicking the '*Save*' button saves all of its configurations (across all tabs, no matter what tab the '*Save*' button is clicked on), including:
# The location of the *JIRA Home Directory* (stored in the {{jira-application.properties}} file within the *JIRA Installation Dierctory*).
# The database connection (stored in the {{dbconfig.xml}} file of the *JIRA Home Directory*).
# The TCP ports that JIRA runs through (stored in the {{server.xml}} file within the *JIRA Installation Dierctory*).

When customers upgrade or install JIRA (using one of the manual upgrade/installation procedures), they can use this tool to perform the first two configurations above (the latter of which may require manual configuration of the {{dbconfig.xml}} file for specialised db setups). Manual configuration of the {{dbconfig.xml}} file might be required because those particular configurations are not supported by the JIRA Configuration Tool.

However, if the customer were to perform the JIRA Home Directory configuration step _after_ defining a finely tuned DB connection (in a 'specialised' {{dbconfig.xml}} file which they manually configured), their specialised {{dbconfig.xml}} will be overwritten because the '*Save*' button on the JIRA Configuration Tool saves the configs on _all_ tabs - regardless of whether you like it or not. End result? They'll then lose their finely tuned configurations.

Hence, please make the '*Save*' button only apply to the configuration tab its used on. Intuitively, many users would also expect the '*Save*' button to behave this way - and it ultimately results in greater flexibility for them too.
fields.summary: Make the JIRA Configuration Tool's 'Save' button only save the configuration of the currently selected tab.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25342].
  {panel}

Jira's URL encoding scheme is incompatible with some web servers, notably IIS 7.5. By default, IIS disallows 'double encoding'. Jira uses this 'double encoding' to replace spaces in the names of file attachments with '+' characters. This causes an error (404 Not Found) when Jira is proxied through IIS with Application Request Routing and URL Rewriting (this is the normal situation with Windows Server 2008 and IIS 7). There is a workaround, but it requires weakening of the default security policy of IIS, which is never easy to swallow.

Using '+' to represent spaces is not universally accepted as a valid practice. The more technically correct (but ugly) encoding of %20 would be safer in a wider variety of situations.

I would like to see Atlassian products use this standard encoding practice.

For background information, please see https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-85127
fields.summary: URL encoding of spaces

fields.description:
Currently when a user changes key graph details, when they close and reopen these are not automatically reactivated until the user goes back into the menu.
Key attributes to be recorded are those in:
•	AXIS Tab
•	SERIES TAB
•	ADVANCED OPTIONS|CHART|LEGEND TAB.
This will help maintain key look and feel of the graphs so the user maintains continuity when reusing modules again and again.
fields.summary: Currently when a user changes key graph details, when they close and reopen these are not automatically reactivated until the user goes back into the menu.

fields.description:
Upon  hitting the "Run Single Module" button in a combination.  All setting from the previous run are lost.  i.e KPI's selected in the graph, Node levels and elements selected etc are all lost, so even if the user is running the same query again all settings have to be re-entered.  These need to be maintained.  Similar to how "Run All Modules" button behaves.
Also when the module is run for the first time,  Even when in "User Preferences" the option for all elements to be automatically selected is activated.  This is not transferred into the graphing component and no elements are selected.

fields.description:
Hi, my boss asked me to request following feature request. Please let me know if you need more details.

There are many different ways issues can be sorted by in Jira, severity, votes, fix versions etc. However, it is not always obvious for the developer which one to sort by - is a blocker with a later fix version more important than a minor issue with a fix version for tomorrow's release?

What I am looking for is some kind of ranking system that assigns weights to the various criteria, multiplies those with numerical values for the various criteria possibilities (e.g. blocker 10, major 5, minor 3... for severity, and number of days until planned release for fix version), and then allows to sort issue lists by that overall ranking. Of course, those weights would have to be configurable by project (preferably with a reasonable default), since they might change depending on the customer, the project manager's preferences etc. It might also be useful to have some kind of "project manager override" ("no matter what the ranking says, I need this done first"). Even weighing in other aspects might be useful, e.g. Submitter (customer X has a Super Important Platinum Premium Diamond Support Contract, and everything they report needs to be top of the list and getting dealt with immediately).
fields.summary: Total importance rating

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25332].
  {panel}

BonFire ended up throw an exception (during restore) and once that is done JIRA is busted forever.  We should use try/catch around the module output to stop this happening.

Also be careful about logging since  a poisoned plugin will log on every page view.
